etymology.description: 小 (little) + 皇帝 (emperor) = pampered, domineering child.
etymology.interpretation: Literally “little emperor,” it labels a spoiled, overindulged child, often an only child who wields outsized authority at home. Common in discussions of post–One-Child Policy family dynamics.

examples.chinese: 在独生子女家庭，他常被当成小皇帝(在獨生子女家庭，他常被當成小皇帝)。
examples.pinyin: Zài dúshēng zǐnǚ jiātíng, tā cháng bèi dàngchéng xiǎo huángdì.
examples.english: In an only-child family, he’s often treated like a little emperor.

examples.chinese: 老师说他很聪明，但脾气像小皇帝一样需要管教(老師說他很聰明，但脾氣像小皇帝一樣需要管教)。
examples.pinyin: Lǎoshī shuō tā hěn cōngmíng, dàn píqì xiàng xiǎo huángdì yíyàng xūyào guǎnjiào.
examples.english: The teacher says he’s smart, but his temper is like a little emperor’s and needs discipline.

examples.chinese: 父母不该把孩子养成小皇帝，否则很难适应社会(父母不該把孩子養成小皇帝，否則很難適應社會)。
examples.pinyin: Fùmǔ bù gāi bǎ háizi yǎngchéng xiǎo huángdì, fǒuzé hěn nán shìyìng shèhuì.
examples.english: Parents shouldn’t raise a child to be a little emperor, or it’ll be hard to adapt to society.
